abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Fair Game column observes Wells Fargo's board, thrust into spotlight over sham accounts scandal, seems to recall its role; says its clawing back of compensation for chief executive John G Stumpf and Carrie Tolstedt is welcome move, although slow in coming.

headline.print_headline: Wells Fargo Board, Suddenly in Spotlight, Seems to Recall Its Role
headline.main: By Taking Back Money, Wells Fargo’s Board Seems to Recall Its Role

snippet: As John G. Stumpf prepares to face a second round of congressional grilling, the bank’s board said he would forfeit about $41 million in stock awards, forgo his salary during the inquiry and receive no bonus in 2016....
lead_paragraph: As John G. Stumpf prepares to face a second round of congressional grilling, the bank’s board said he would forfeit about $41 million in stock awards, forgo his salary during the inquiry and receive no bonus in 2016.
